Hyperbolic and trigonometric functions

We have seen previously that \[\qquad e^{i\theta}=\cos\theta +i\sin\theta\] It follows from this that \[\qquad e^{-i\theta}=\cos (-\theta)+i\sin (-\theta)=\cos\theta -i\sin\theta\] Now if we add these two relations together we obtain \[\qquad \cos\theta ={e^{i\theta}+e^{-i\theta}\over {2}}\] whereas if we subtract the second from the first we have\[\qquad \sin\theta ={e^{i\theta}-e^{-i\theta}\over {2i}}\] These new relations are reminiscent of the hyperbolic functions introduced in a previous quiz. There we defined \(\cosh x\) and \(\sinh x\) in terms of the exponential function: \[\qquad \cosh x ={e^{x}+e^{-x}\over {2}}\qquad \sinh x ={e^{x}-e^{-x}\over {2}}\] In fact, if we replace \(x\) by \(i\theta\) in these last two equations we obtain \[\qquad \cosh (i\theta) ={e^{i\theta } +e^{-i\theta}\over 2}\equiv \cos \theta\qquad \text{and}\qquad \sinh (i\theta) ={e^{i\theta } -e^{-i\theta}\over 2}\equiv i\sin \theta\] Although, by our notation, we have implied that both \(x\) and \(\theta\) are real quantities in fact these expressions for \(\cosh\) and \(\sinh\) in terms of \(\cos\) and \(\sin\) are quite general.

Key Point

If \(z\) is any complex number then \[\cosh(iz) \equiv \cos z\quad\text{and}\quad\sinh(iz) \equiv i\sin z\] Equivalently, replacing \(z\) by \(iz\): \[\cosh z \equiv \cos(iz) \quad\text{and}\quad i\sinh z \equiv \sin(iz)\]
